newsitem.title: UK: Eurotunnel slides as deal fails to convince.
newsitem.headline: Eurotunnel slides as deal fails to convince.

text.p: Shares in debt-laden Eurotunnel slid again on Wednesday on both sides of the English Channel as doubts about the subsea railway operator's new debt relief deal prompted heavy selling, analysts said.

The shares resumed trading on Monday after being suspended for a week while the company finished negotiated the refinancing 8.7 billion pounds ($13.59 billion) of debt. The shares have slipped 24p to 89-1/2p so far this week -- over 20 percent down since the deal was unveiled two days ago.
Brokers UBS, a long-time bear of the stock, reiterated its sell stance warning Eurotunnel would continue to be substantially cash negative well into the next decade.
"The swap of debt to equity doesn't really look big enough to be a proper long term refinancing," said UBS analyst Richard Hannah.

"The equity value is pretty minimal on our model and the value of the equity seems to be of "voting" value rather than economic. We think the shares are seriously overvalued at the moment and that's before the dilution comes through," he said.
UBS calculates that the total net present value of the cash stream from Eurotunnel's remaining 52-year tunnel operating concession at below six billion pounds, well short of its total remaining debt.
